name: Dobble
description:
Do you know the game *Dobble*? It is a game with 55 cards, with 8 different pictures on each card, such that every two cards have **exactly one** picture in common. The total amount of different pictures is 57. For this kata, the pictures are represented by numbers `1,2,...,57`. Your task is to produce a possible Dobble card set `dobble`, i.e. a set/array of at least 55 pieces of 8-tuples `(a0,a1,a2,...,a7)` where `1 <= a0Example If `a = (1,2,3,4,5,6,7,8)` and `b = (8,9,10,11,12,13,14,15)` are two cards in the card set, then neither `u = (15,16,17,18,19,20,21,22)` nor `v = (1,9,15,16,17,18,19,20)` can appear in the card set, because `u` doesn't meet `a` in any common picture whereas `v` meets `b` in *two* common pictures: `9` and `15`. At the same time, `c = (1,9,16,17,18,19,20,21)` fits together with `a` and `b` in the card set. ---------------------

*Hint:*

Besides pure combinatorics, one can generate a dobble card set using some finite geometry. The observation is that points and lines behave similarly as the dobble card set, in that every two points determine a unique line. So, let dobble cards correspond to points and the pictures to lines. The finite plane over the integers modulo 7 consists of 49 points. We can work with two integer coordinates modulo 7 to represent a point or vector here. Moreover, any line can be written as `[P + i*d for i in range(7)]` with given starting point `P` and direction vector `d`. So, each line has 7 points here, and by counting the direction vectors, we find that each point lies on exactly 8 lines, which will in turn imply that altogether the plane has 56 lines. The missing 57th 'line' and some other 'points' are waiting for you to get discovered.

*Hint on the hint:*

Try to work out a smaller example, say modulo 3, to find and count all the appearing directions and lines in the corresponding finite plane of 9 points.
